sub_title: Head of Research & Innovation, Dept. of Pathology at the Netherlands Cancer Institute; Professor of Oncologic Pathology at University Medical Center Utrecht; co-Founder & CSO at CRCbioscreen, CSO Health-RI
summary:
Gerrit Meijer is professor of pathology with a special interest in cancer research, focusing on the gastrointestinal tract. After finishing medical school at the Vrije Universiteit (VU) Amsterdam he completed his PhD on “Risk assessment in patients with colorectal adenomas”. He pursued his research during his training in pathology, with a special attention to phenotype-genotype relationships in the context of translational research. 
Professor Meijer leads a translational research group that focuses on gastrointestinal cancer. This involves omics based tumour profiling, using DNA, RNA and proteomics based techniques, in order to stratify patient groups and arrive at individual tailored therapies. Furthermore, genomic and proteomics profiling of pre-malignant lesions is used for biomarker discovery to improve (colorectal) cancer screening. Building infrastructure to support this translational research is another focus. Professor Meijer stood at the basis of the successful implementation of comparative genomic hybridization in the Department of Pathology, VU University Medical Center (VUmc), and was one of the initiators in the field of DNA micro-array technology at VUmc. IT infrastructure for translational research and a bioinformatics dry lab complete these facilities. 
As to management, Gerrit Meijer is chair of the department of pathology, member of the board of directors of the Cancer Center Amsterdam / the VUmc Research Institute for Oncology and Immunology, has served as director of the Oncology Graduate School Amsterdam and editor in chief of Cellular Oncology. Professor Meijer has been involved in multiple courses for undergraduate and graduate students in medicine and biology, as well as for residents in pathology and other specialties, and has served as program leader for the masters in Oncology at VUmc.
Starting March 1, 2015, he has joined the Netherlands Cancer Institute as head of the department of pathology and group leader.

projects: [{'title': 'BBMRI-NL Dutch National Tissue Portal', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'This project aims to optimize secondary use of tissue samples for translational research, building on the Dutch national pathology data archive PALGA and the tissue archives of the >55 pathology labs in the Netherlands', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Gerrit', 'last_name': 'Meijer', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Research & Innovation, Dept. of Pathology at the Netherlands Cancer Institute; Professor of Oncologic Pathology at University Medical Center Utrecht; co-Founder & CSO at CRCbioscreen, CSO Health-RI'}, {'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Folkert', 'last_name': 'Van Kemenade', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Chair, professor of Pathology at Erasmus MC'}, {'type': 'nonStandardizedContributor', 'first_name': None, 'last_name': None, 'name': 'Lucy Overbeek', 'headline': None}]}, {'title': 'CTMM TraIT', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The CTMM Translational Research IT (TraIT) project aims to develop a long-lasting IT infrastructure for the Netherlands that will facilitate the collection, storage, analysis, archiving and securing of the data generated in the CTMM’s twenty-one operational research projects. The TraIT project differs from other CTMM projects in that it is not directly designed to turn fundamental science into applied healthcare. Instead, it aims to use proven ICT (Information and Communication Technology) to create an IT infrastructure that will help to accelerate the translational research being carried out in the other projects. The TraIT project is a joint initiative between CTMM, the Dutch Cancer Society, the Dutch Heart Foundation, the Netherlands Federation of University Medical Centers (NFU), the Netherlands Bioinformatics Centre (NBIC), the String of Pearls Initiative (PSI) and the Netherlands eScience Center (NLeSC).', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Gerrit', 'last_name': 'Meijer', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Research & Innovation, Dept. of Pathology at the Netherlands Cancer Institute; Professor of Oncologic Pathology at University Medical Center Utrecht; co-Founder & CSO at CRCbioscreen, CSO Health-RI'}]}, {'title': 'CTMM DeCoDe', 'date': {'start': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The DeCoDe project is a breakthrough in translational colorectal cancer research in the Netherlands.
